overview_of_class: This course examines the links between illegal drugs and politics, from the politics of local communities to international public policy. The production, distribution, and consumption of illicit drugs affect politics in a myriad of ways by shaping individual behavior, local and national institutions, cultural practices, markets, and international relations. The aim of the course is to examine these linkstheoretically and empiricallywith a focus on North, Central, and South America. We will critically analyze public policy on "the drugs problem", especially the US-led "war on drugs".
name: Drugs and Politics
title: WCAS POLI_SCI 377-0-20 Drugs and Politics

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course examines the links between illegal drugs and politics, from the politics of local communities to international public policy. The production, distribution, and consumption of illicit drugs affect politics in a myriad of ways by shaping individual behavior, local and national institutions, cultural practices, markets, and international relations. The aim of the course is to examine these linkstheoretically and empiricallywith a focus on North, Central, and South America. We will critically analyze public policy on "the drugs problem", especially the US-led "war on drugs".

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
(i) Students will acquire a critical understanding of the local, national, and regional dynamics of the illicit drug trade.
(ii) Students will be able to identify relations between contemporary Latin American major problems (like corruption and violence) and the illicit drug trade.
(iii) Students will acquire a critical understanding of the role that illicit drugs play in U.S.-Latin American relations.
(iv) Students will acquire a critical understanding of public policy on illicit drugs.
(v) Students will improve their analytical skills for studying political and social phenomena. In particular, they will improve their capacity to evaluate statements about causality.
(v) Students will improve their analytical skills for studying public policy. In particular, they will improve their capacity to evaluate normative and positive statements and the links between them.
